title: Robotron KC 87
text:
The Robotron KC 87, fully known as the Kleincomputer robotron KC 87 ("KC" standing for "Kleincomputer", lit. "small computer"), was an <a href="8-bit">8-bit</a> <a href="home%20computer">home computer</a> released in 1987 and produced in <a href="East%20Germany">East Germany</a> by the <a href="Volkseigener%20Betrieb">VEB</a> <a href="VEB%20Robotron">Robotron</a>-Meßelektronik "Otto Schön" <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a>, part of the <a href="Combine%20%28enterprise%29">Kombinat</a> <a href="VEB%20Robotron">Robotron</a>.
The first model in the series, the Robotron Z 9001, was introduced in 1984 and renamed Robotron KC 85/1 in 1985. Despite similar names, the Robotron home computers were not directly related to the <a href="KC%2085">KC 85</a> series produced by the <a href="Kombinat%20Mikroelektronik%20Erfurt">VEB Mikroelektronik</a> "<a href="Wilhelm%20Pieck">Wilhelm Pieck</a>" <a href="M%C3%BChlhausen">Mühlhausen</a>.
The availability of the Robotron KC series for private customers was very limited. The computers were mostly used at educational institutions, organizations, and enterprises. Therefore, the <a href="Extracurricular%20activity">extracurricular</a> use of home computers was often allowed for students at institutions and organizations.
Design.
The Robotron KC series used an <a href="U880">U880</a> <a href="microprocessor">microprocessor</a>, a clone of the <a href="Zilog%20Z80">Zilog Z80</a>, which was clocked at 2.5 MHz. The keyboard was integrated into every machine. Software could be loaded from <a href="cassette%20tape">cassette tape</a>s; a separate <a href="cassette%20deck">cassette deck</a> was needed for doing so. All models featured module slots for up to four expansion modules, which allowed expansion of the hardware, such as by upgrading the <a href="Random-access%20memory">RAM</a> or allowing it to connect to a <a href="printer%20%28computing%29">printer</a>, but also included <a href="application%20software">applications</a> and <a href="programming%20language">programming language</a>s. The KC 87 had the <a href="BASIC">BASIC</a> <a href="Interpreter%20%28computing%29">interpreter</a> in <a href="Read-only%20memory">ROM</a>, (in earlier models, the user had to load it from tape or use a BASIC expansion module). In addition to the home computers, Robotron also offered cassette tapes with applications and <a href="video%20game">games</a>, modules, and other equipment.
